question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. There have been ongoing efforts to disqualify Trump from running for office under this clause due to his role in the January 6, 2021, storming of the U.S. Capitol. However, the process of disqualifying a candidate under Section 3 is complex and requires a state or federal court to rule that the individual has engaged in insurrection or rebellion. As of the current date, there have been no confirmed reports of Trump being officially removed or blocked from any state's primary election ballot under Section 3. While there is a possibility that this could happen before July 15, 2024, it is uncertain and depends on various legal and political factors. Therefore, based on the current information and the complexity of the process, I estimate the probability of Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024, to be relatively low.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To determine the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024, we need to consider several factors, including his health, political stability, and potential risks. As of the current date (July 5, 2024), Biden has been President for over three years and has shown no indication of resigning or facing imminent removal from office. While it's impossible to predict with certainty, we can assess the likelihood based on historical trends and available information. 1. Health Risks: Biden's age (born November 20, 1942) is a factor, but he has been relatively healthy and active. Without specific information suggesting otherwise, it's reasonable to assume he will remain healthy enough to continue in office for the next month. 2. Political Stability: The political landscape in the United States is often contentious, but as of now, there are no significant indicators that Biden faces an immediate threat to his presidency from impeachment proceedings or other political maneuvers. 3. Accidental Death or Incapacitation: This is always a possibility for anyone, regardless of age or health status. However, given the security measures in place for the President, the risk is minimized. 4. Resignation: There has been no credible speculation or indication that Biden intends to resign before the end of July 2024. Considering these factors, the likelihood of Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 appears high. However, because unforeseen events can always occur, the probability cannot be 100.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking about the likelihood of at least 20 House/Senate Democrats signing a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early. The context provided suggests that there is already a drafted letter circulating among Democrats, and Rep. Jared Huffman has expressed strong opposition to the early nomination plan. Additionally, the fact that 'dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out' implies that there is a significant number of Democrats who are unhappy with the plan. However, it's unclear how many of these Democrats will ultimately sign a public letter. Given the strong language used by Huffman and the fact that a letter is already being circulated, I believe it's likely that at least 20 Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of both events occurring, we need to break down the question into its components and assess each individually before combining them. (a) Joe Biden announcing before July 15, 2024, that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President: As of my last update, there has been no significant indication from Joe Biden or his team that he intends to step down or not seek the Democratic nomination for the 2024 presidential election. Given the typical political climate and the importance of the presidential election, it's reasonable to assume that if Biden were to make such an announcement, it would be a significant political event. However, without concrete evidence or recent statements suggesting otherwise, it's challenging to assign a high probability to this event. Historically, incumbent presidents who have chosen not to run for re-election have often made their intentions known well in advance, but there's always a degree of uncertainty until official announcements are made. Probability: 0.2 (b) A person representing the Republican Party wins the special election for Ohio's 6th congressional district before January 1, 2025: Ohio's 6th congressional district has historically been a Republican stronghold. While special elections can be unpredictable due to various factors such as turnout and the specific candidates involved, the district's voting history suggests a Republican candidate would have a favorable chance of winning. However, without knowing the specific candidates, the timing of the election, and other factors that could influence the outcome, it's difficult to assign a very high probability. Still, given the district's leanings, a Republican win seems more likely than not. Probability: 0.65. To find the combined probability of both events happening, we multiply the probabilities of each event: 0.2 (Biden not seeking nomination) * 0.65 (Republican winning Ohio's 6th district) = 0.13. Therefore, the estimated probability that both specified events will occur is 0.13. The calculation is based on the individual probabilities assigned to each event, considering historical context, political climate, and the nature of special elections. The combined probability reflects the uncertainty and the relatively low likelihood of both events occurring as specified.

question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced that new tariffs or duties will be imposed that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The European Union has been actively engaged in trade negotiations and disputes with China in recent years, and the automotive sector is a significant area of contention. The EU has already imposed tariffs on certain Chinese goods, including steel and solar panels, and has been investigating whether to impose duties on Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) due to concerns over unfair subsidies and dumping practices. Given the existing trade tensions and the ongoing investigation, it is plausible that the EU might announce new tariffs or duties on Chinese EVs before July 5, 2024. However, it is also possible that the EU might choose to delay or abandon such measures due to various factors, such as diplomatic efforts, industry lobbying, or changes in market conditions.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is about whether a group of at least 5 named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators will work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign before July 20th. The Politico report suggests that there is already some momentum behind this effort, with two safe-seat members publicly urging Biden to drop out and multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats. However, it's worth noting that the market requires a group of at least 5 named individuals to work together, which is a higher bar than just individual members expressing their opinions. Additionally, the market requires that the names of these individuals be made public, which could be a challenge given the potential for anonymous sources and leaks. Despite these challenges, the fact that there are already efforts underway to draft letters and that some members have publicly spoken out against Biden's candidacy suggests that there is a possibility of a group of at least 5 named members working together to pressure Biden to drop out.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question asks whether Joe Biden will remain President of the United States through the end of July 2024. To answer this question, we need to consider the likelihood of various events that could lead to his removal from office before the specified date. These events include resignation, death, or other circumstances that would cause him to cease being President. First, let's consider the possibility of resignation. While it's impossible to predict with certainty, there is no current indication that Biden plans to resign. He has shown no signs of intending to step down, and his administration has not hinted at any such plans. Therefore, the likelihood of resignation seems low. Next, we consider the possibility of death. Unfortunately, mortality is an unpredictable event, and it's impossible to rule out the possibility entirely. However, Biden's health has been relatively stable, and there is no public indication of any serious health concerns that would suggest a high risk of death in the near future. Other circumstances that could lead to Biden ceasing to be President are also unlikely. There is no ongoing impeachment process or other constitutional mechanism that would suggest a high likelihood of removal from office. Given these considerations, it seems reasonable to conclude that the likelihood of Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 is relatively high.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. To assess this, we must consider the legal and political landscape. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. The clause has been invoked in recent years in the context of the January 6, 2021, storming of the U.S. Capitol, with some arguing that Trump's actions or inactions on that day could be seen as supporting an insurrection. However, the application of this clause is not straightforward and would likely involve legal challenges and interpretations by courts. As of my last update, there have been discussions and legal actions related to this topic, but no definitive nationwide ruling or consensus on its application to Trump's candidacy. Given the complexity of the legal process, the necessity for state-by-state decisions, and the timeframe provided (up to July 15, 2024), there are several factors to consider: 1. Legal Proceedings: The legal process is slow and unpredictable. For Trump to be officially removed or blocked by July 15, 2024, under Section 3, there would need to be swift and decisive legal action across one or more states, which is challenging given the typical pace of legal proceedings. 2. Political Considerations: The decision to remove or block a major political figure like Trump from ballots is highly politicized. States controlled by Republicans might be less inclined to take such actions, while Democratic-controlled states might be more inclined. However, the legal basis for such a decision would need to be robust to withstand potential legal challenges. 3. Public and Media Pressure: Public opinion and media pressure could influence political will, but the question specifically requires official actions or court decisions, not public opinion or media speculation. Considering these factors, while there is a possibility that legal challenges could result in Trump being removed or blocked from a primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, the complexity, the political polarization, and the legal hurdles make this outcome less likely than not.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking whether a group of at least 5 named Democratic Party US House Members or US Senators will work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign before July 20th. Additionally, two endangered Democrats have privately written off Biden's chances of winning in November. While this suggests that there is some momentum behind the idea of Biden dropping out, it is unclear whether a group of at least 5 named Democrats will come together to make a public call for him to do so. However, given the reports of multiple drafts of letters circulating and the fact that some Democrats have already publicly spoken out against Biden's candidacy, I think it is plausible that a group of at least 5 named Democrats could come together to make a public call for Biden to drop out before July 20th.

question.title: Will GUE/NGL hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if GUE/NGL holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other political groups. If two groups are tied for seats, both will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The European United Left-Nordic Green Left (GUE/NGL) is a left-wing political group within the European Parliament. Historically, the group has held a relatively small number of seats, with their highest share being around 10% of the total seats. In the 2019 European Parliament election, the GUE/NGL group secured 41 seats out of 751, which is roughly 5.5%. They ranked fifth in terms of the number of seats held. Given their past performance and the current European political landscape, it seems unlikely that GUE/NGL would gain enough seats to surpass other major groups such as the European People's Party (EPP), the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D), and Renew Europe. While it's difficult to predict the exact outcome of the 2024 European Parliament elections, the historical data suggests that GUE/NGL would face significant challenges in becoming the largest group in the parliament. However, European politics can be unpredictable, and various factors such as voter turnout, coalition dynamics, and the impact of rising nationalist movements could potentially influence the outcome.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given the trends in public opinion polls and the specific context of Manifold respondents, there's a plausible scenario where Trump performs better against Biden than against a generic Democrat. However, the representativeness of Manifold respondents and the specific dynamics of these polls introduce uncertainty.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. This requires a careful analysis of the political and legal landscape. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. While there have been efforts to invoke this clause against Trump, the legal and political hurdles to actually removing him from the ballot are significant. As of my knowledge cutoff, there is no clear indication that any state has officially removed or blocked Trump from the primary election ballot under this clause. Furthermore, the question requires confirmation through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports, which adds an extra layer of difficulty in resolving the question positively. Given these challenges, I estimate the probability of Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, to be relatively low.

question.title: If Joe Biden drops out, will a reliable media outlet cover the story at least 6 hours in advance?
question.body:
Question resolves YES if a big and reliable media outlet like Associated Press News, CNN, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Fox News, Reuters, or Washington Post covers the dropout with an unofficial confirmation at least 6 hours before President Joe Biden officially announces his dropout via letter, speech, etc.

Local news, conspiracy websites, or comments by individual users on Manifold will not be sufficient.

This market will be resolved as N/A if President Joe Biden does not drop out before the end of the National Democratic Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This question revolves around the likelihood of a reliable media outlet covering a significant political event, specifically Joe Biden dropping out, at least 6 hours before the official announcement. Several factors influence this probability: 1. Reliability and Vigilance of Major Media Outlets: Major news outlets like the Associated Press, CNN, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Fox News, Reuters, and Washington Post have a strong track record of breaking news, especially on significant political events. Their resources and networks of journalists and sources are extensive, increasing the likelihood of them obtaining and verifying such information in advance. 2. Timing and Sensitivity of Political News: Political news, particularly involving a major figure like the President, is highly sensitive and closely watched. The news cycle is 24/7, and the competition among outlets to break stories first is fierce. This environment incentivizes outlets to report as soon as they have reliable information. 3. Pre-announcement Rumors and Leaks: In the political sphere, especially at the level of a presidential campaign, rumors and leaks are common. If there is any credible indication that Joe Biden is considering dropping out, it is likely that at least one major outlet would pick up on this and report it, given the significance of the story. 4. Verification Process: While outlets want to be first, they also need to maintain credibility. Thus, they have verification processes in place, which might slightly delay the reporting but ensure that when they do report, the information is reliable. This process supports the possibility of reporting at least 6 hours in advance, as it allows time for verification. 5. The Specific Time Frame of 6 Hours: The question specifies 'at least 6 hours' before the official announcement. This time frame is reasonable for a major news outlet to obtain, verify, and prepare a story on a significant event like a presidential dropout, especially considering the 24-hour news cycle and the speed of information dissemination. Given these considerations, it's reasonable to conclude that if Joe Biden were to drop out, the likelihood of a reliable media outlet covering the story at least 6 hours in advance is quite high.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:

This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. To assess this, we need to consider several factors: 1. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment: This section, also known as the Disqualification Clause, prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. Trump's involvement in the January 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol attack has led to discussions about his potential disqualification under this clause. 2. Ongoing litigation and investigations: There are ongoing lawsuits and investigations into Trump's actions, including his role in the January 6 attack. These could potentially lead to his disqualification from the ballot. 3. State-level decisions: The decision to remove or block Trump from the primary election ballot would need to be made at the state level. This would require state officials or courts to take action under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. 4. Timeframe: The question specifically asks about the situation as of July 15, 2024. This gives a relatively short timeframe for any potential litigation or state-level decisions to be made. Considering these factors, it seems plausible that there could be attempts to remove or block Trump from the primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. However, the likelihood of such attempts being successful and resulting in Trump's removal from the ballot by July 15, 2024, is uncertain. Given the complexity of the issue, the ongoing litigation and investigations, and the short timeframe, I would estimate the probability of Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, as follows:

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking about the probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. To assess this probability, we need to consider the current political climate, the health of President Biden, and the likelihood of the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet invoking Section 4. As of the current date (July 5, 2024), there is no public information suggesting that President Biden's health is deteriorating or that he is unable to discharge his duties as President. While there have been some concerns about his age and health in the past, there is no concrete evidence to suggest that he is incapacitated. Furthermore, invoking Section 4 of the 25th Amendment is a serious and rare step that requires a significant amount of evidence and consensus among the Vice President and the Cabinet. It is not a decision that would be taken lightly, and it would likely require a major crisis or a significant deterioration in the President's health. Given these factors, it seems unlikely that President Biden will be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. While it is impossible to rule out any possibility entirely, the current evidence and circumstances suggest that this outcome is unlikely.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This question is asking for the probability that Trump's lead over Biden will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average. To answer this question, we need to consider the current polling trends and the historical volatility of polling averages. As of the question's creation date (July 9, 2024), the 538 national polling average shows Trump leading Biden by 2.4 points. However, polling averages can fluctuate over time due to various factors such as changes in voter sentiment, polling methodology, and sampling errors. Given the current lead of 2.4 points, it is possible that Trump's lead could increase or decrease by a small margin over the next six days (until July 15, 2024). However, a significant increase or decrease in the lead is less likely, as polling averages tend to be relatively stable over short periods. Considering these factors, I estimate that the probability of Trump's lead being greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, is around 60%. This probability reflects the uncertainty associated with polling averages and the potential for small fluctuations in the lead over the next six days.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: A brokered convention occurs when no candidate receives a majority of the votes on the first ballot, leading to multiple rounds of voting. While it's difficult to predict with certainty, historical trends and current political dynamics can provide some insight. In recent years, the Democratic Party has experienced increased polarization and fragmentation, which could lead to a more contested nomination process. Additionally, the large field of candidates in the 2024 primary season increases the likelihood of a brokered convention. However, it's worth noting that the Democratic Party has implemented rules changes aimed at reducing the likelihood of a brokered convention, such as the use of proportional allocation of delegates. Taking these factors into account, I estimate the probability of a brokered convention at 35%.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of both events occurring, I'll break down the reasoning for each event and then combine them. Event (a): Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024 A brokered convention occurs when no candidate receives a majority of delegates in the first round of voting, leading to multiple rounds of voting. This is relatively rare in modern US politics. In recent history, the last brokered convention was in 1952. For the 2024 Democratic convention, it's difficult to predict with certainty, but we can look at some factors: The Democratic Party has a large field of candidates, which increases the likelihood of a brokered convention. However, the party has implemented rules changes aimed at reducing the likelihood of a brokered convention, such as superdelegates and debate qualification thresholds. The current front-runners have significant support, but it's unclear if any will reach a majority of delegates before the convention. The emergence of a strong alternative candidate. The party's perception of Biden's electability and ability to win the general election. Currently, Biden is the incumbent president and has significant support within the party. While some Democrats have expressed concerns about his age and electability, it's unclear if this will translate to a large number of Senators calling for him to drop out. I estimate the probability of 10 or more Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out before July 20 at around 10-15%. This is a rough estimate, as it's difficult to predict the actions of individual Senators. Combined probability: To estimate the probability of both events occurring, we can multiply the individual probabilities: 0.20-0.25 (brokered convention) × 0.10-0.15 (10+ Senators call for Biden to drop out) = 0.02-0.0375. question.title: Will France place in the Top 5 at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if France place in the top 5 (ties resolve positively) at the Olympics being held in 2024. It will resolve ambiguously if the Olympics do not take place in 2024.

The medal table is calculated by taking the total number of medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medal

metadata.chain_of_thought: France's historical performance, home advantage, and investment in sports infrastructure suggest a strong chance of placing in the top 5, but intense competition from other countries prevents a very high probability.

(b) France places in the Top 5 at the 2024 Paris Olympics, resolving positively if France is in the top 5 (ties included) based on the medal count calculated by:

The question resolves ambiguously if the Olympics do not take place in 2024.

question.title: Will the United States win gold in both Men's and Women's 5v5 basketball at the Paris Olympics
question.body: Resolves Yes if Team USA wins both gold medals. Resolves no if either the men's or women's team places anywhere other than gold.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The United States has traditionally been a dominant force in basketball, with a strong track record of success in international competitions. In the Olympics, the US men's team has won 16 gold medals, including three in a row from 2008 to 2016, before losing to France in the 2020 Olympics. The US women's team has also been highly successful, winning 9 gold medals, including 7 in a row from 1996 to 2020. However, the competition in both men's and women's basketball has been increasing in recent years, with other countries such as Spain, Australia, and China improving their teams. Additionally, the Olympics are a single-elimination tournament, which means that a single loss can eliminate a team from contention. Therefore, while the US teams are likely to be strong contenders, there is a significant risk of an upset or a loss to a well-prepared opponent.

question.title: Will the Pandemic Agreement be approved at the May 2024 World Health Assembly?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, during the May 2024 World Health Assembly (WHA) the Pandemic Agreement is approved in a vote, according to reports from credible sources.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Pandemic Agreement is a proposed international treaty aimed at strengthening global health security and preventing future pandemics. The World Health Assembly (WHA) is the decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO), and it is responsible for approving international health agreements. In recent years, the WHA has shown a willingness to adopt new agreements and resolutions to address global health challenges. Given the current global health landscape and the need for enhanced international cooperation to prevent and respond to pandemics, it is likely that the Pandemic Agreement will receive significant support from WHO member states. Additionally, the agreement has been under negotiation for several years, and many countries have already expressed their commitment to its principles and objectives. While there may be some debate and negotiation during the WHA, it is likely that the agreement will be approved, given the broad support it has received from the international community. However, there is always a degree of uncertainty in international diplomacy, and it is possible that some countries may raise objections or concerns that could delay or block the agreement's approval.

question.title: Will OpenAI publicly commit to the "no retaliation for public risk disclosure" principle before July 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if, before July 1, 2024, both of the following are true:

- OpenAI publicly commits to the "no retaliation for public risk disclosure" principle via a statement from the company or a company spokesperson, such as Sam Altman. The statement may be formal (such as a press release) or informal (such as a tweet or quote in an interview). The statement from OpenAI must indicate a new level of commitment to the principle in question, relative to the time the righttowarn.ai statement was published; it cannot be a reiteration that, for example, "we already have a culture of open criticism". 
- Metaculus verifies that the company has accepted the principle to the satisfaction of at least one member of righttowarn.ai. Metaculus may reach out to select signatories or endorsers to assess their level of satisfaction with OpenAI's commitment. Statements must be at least as rigorous as "this was a good first step" for this question to resolve as **Yes**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: OpenAI has been actively engaging with the AI safety community and has shown a willingness to listen to concerns and adapt its policies. The "no retaliation for public risk disclosure" principle is a key aspect of responsible AI development, and OpenAI may see the benefits of publicly committing to this principle to maintain a positive reputation and build trust with stakeholders. Additionally, the involvement of righttowarn.ai and the requirement for Metaculus verification adds a level of accountability and transparency to the process, which could encourage OpenAI to make a genuine commitment. However, there is always a risk that OpenAI may not prioritize this issue or may not be willing to make a public commitment, especially if it perceives potential drawbacks or liabilities. Given the timeframe of approximately 2 months, it is possible that OpenAI may not have sufficient time to carefully consider and publicly commit to this principle.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. The clause has been invoked in the context of the January 6, 2021, storming of the U.S. Capitol, with some arguing that Trump's actions or inactions could be seen as supporting or inciting the insurrection, thus potentially disqualifying him under this clause. However, the application of Section 3 is complex and requires specific legal actions and determinations. As of my last update in September 2023, there were ongoing legal debates and discussions about the potential application of Section 3 to Trump, but no definitive action had been taken by any state to remove him from the ballot under this clause. Given the legal hurdles, the necessity for specific state actions, and the timeframe provided (up to July 15, 2024), the probability of Donald Trump being officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by the specified date seems relatively low. - Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare

(b) This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024. Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

question.title: Will a terrorist act occur in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics?
question.body:
The question will resolve as Yes if a terrorist attack in [Metropolitan France](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolitan_France) injures and/or kills at least one person, other than the terrorist(s), between, and inclusive of, the day of the Opening Ceremony (26 July 2024) and the day of the Closing Ceremony (11 August 2024). The question will resolve as No if the above does not happen.

An event will be considered a 'terrorist attack' if it is described as such by any agency of the State of France, or by the French President, Prime Minister, or a member of the Council of Ministers.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Assessing the probability of a terrorist act occurring in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics is inherently challenging due to the unpredictable nature of such events. However, several factors can be considered to make an informed estimate. Firstly, France has experienced terrorist attacks in the past, most notably the November 2015 Paris attacks and the July 2016 Nice truck attack, which indicate a precedent for such threats. Secondly, major international events like the Olympics can be attractive targets for terrorists seeking to maximize impact. On the other hand, France has significantly enhanced its security measures since those attacks, including the establishment of a state of emergency that has been in place in various forms and the deployment of a large number of security personnel during major events. The country's intelligence services are also on high alert during such periods. Given these considerations, while there is a clear risk, the enhanced security posture and past experiences suggest that the probability, though difficult to quantify precisely, should be considered as present but not overwhelmingly high.

However, since the question asks for the probability of Trump's lead being greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3, we need to adjust the probability to account for the fact that a lead of exactly 3 points is included in the range. Assuming a uniform distribution of possible leads within the range, the probability of Trump's lead being exactly 3 points is relatively low. Therefore, we'll adjust the probability downward to 0.65.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking whether President Biden will be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. To answer this question, we need to consider the likelihood of the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet invoking Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office. The context provided mentions that a GOP lawmaker has asked Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office, which suggests that there may be some political pressure to declare Biden incapacitated. However, it is essential to note that the 25th Amendment is a constitutional provision that requires a high threshold of evidence and consensus among the Vice President and the Cabinet to invoke. Given the current political climate and the lack of any publicly available information suggesting that Biden is incapacitated, it is unlikely that the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet would invoke Section 4 of the 25th Amendment. The invocation of the 25th Amendment would be a significant political event that would likely require a consensus among the Cabinet and the Vice President, which is difficult to achieve, especially in a polarized political environment. Moreover, the fact that Biden has not invoked Section 3 of the 25th Amendment, which allows the President to temporarily transfer power to the Vice President, suggests that he is not currently incapacitated. Therefore, based on the available information and the high threshold required to invoke the 25th Amendment, I estimate the probability of Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 to be low.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: A brokered convention occurs when no candidate has a majority of delegates after the first round of voting, requiring additional rounds of voting to determine the nominee. In recent years, the Democratic Party has implemented rules changes aimed at reducing the likelihood of a brokered convention, such as superdelegates being unable to vote on the first ballot. However, the large field of candidates in the 2024 primary and the proportional allocation of delegates in many states increases the likelihood of a brokered convention. Additionally, the party's rules allow for delegates to switch their allegiance after the first round of voting, which could lead to a prolonged nomination process. Given these factors, I estimate the probability of a brokered convention at 0.35.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

Organization and Drafting of the Letter: The fact that a letter has already been drafted and is being circulated among House Democrats indicates a level of organization and commitment among those opposed to the early nomination plan. This suggests that there is a tangible effort underway to gather support. 2. Public Signal of Discontent: The drafting of the letter and its circulation signify the first public signal of discontent among Democrats regarding the party's plan. This public display of disagreement can encourage others who might be harboring similar sentiments to join in, potentially increasing the number of signatories. 3. Quotes from Involved Lawmakers: Comments from Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) express strong dissatisfaction with the DNC's plan, calling it a 'really bad move' and suggesting that it won't achieve the desired unity. Such vocal criticism from within the party can galvanize opposition and attract more lawmakers to sign the letter. 4. Timing and Deadline: The market resolves before the end of Sunday, July 21st, providing a specific deadline for the action to occur. The existence of a deadline can focus efforts and encourage those who are inclined to oppose the plan to take action sooner rather than later. 5. Threshold for Resolution: The requirement for at least 20 signatures from House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party is specific. Given the context that 'dozens of House Democrats are organizing,' it seems plausible that this threshold could be met, especially considering that multiple letters with a combined total of 20 signatures would also suffice. Considering these points, while there's no guarantee of success in gathering at least 20 signatures, the context suggests a concerted effort among House Democrats to express their opposition. The specific deadline, the level of organization, and the public display of discontent all contribute to a scenario where meeting the threshold of 20 signatures appears feasible.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking for the probability that President Biden will be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. To answer this question, we need to consider the likelihood of the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet invoking Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office. There have been no credible reports or indications that President Biden is incapacitated or unable to perform his duties as President. In fact, he has been actively engaged in his presidential duties and has shown no signs of incapacitation. Additionally, the 25th Amendment is a serious constitutional provision that is not taken lightly, and it would require a significant and compelling reason for the Vice President and the Cabinet to invoke it. Furthermore, the political climate in the United States is highly polarized, and the invocation of the 25th Amendment would be a highly controversial and partisan move. It is unlikely that the Vice President and the Cabinet would take such a drastic step without overwhelming evidence of the President's incapacitation. Given these considerations, I believe that the probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 is extremely low.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:

This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: A brokered convention occurs when no candidate receives a majority of delegates during the initial voting round, leading to subsequent rounds of voting until a candidate is nominated. Historically, brokered conventions have been rare, with the last one occurring in 1952 for the Democrats and 1948 for the Republicans. In recent years, the Democratic Party has implemented rules to reduce the likelihood of a brokered convention, such as superdelegates and proportional allocation of delegates. However, the 2024 Democratic primary field is expected to be large and diverse, with many strong candidates. This could lead to a fragmented delegate count, increasing the chances of a brokered convention. Additionally, the Democratic Party has made changes to its nomination process, such as eliminating superdelegates from the first round of voting, which could also contribute to a more contested convention. Given these factors, while a brokered convention is still unlikely, it is not impossible. The large field of candidates and changes to the nomination process increase the chances of a contested convention, but the party's efforts to reduce the likelihood of a brokered convention and the historical rarity of such events temper this assessment.

question.title: Will the Pandemic Agreement be approved at the May 2024 World Health Assembly?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, during the May 2024 World Health Assembly (WHA) the Pandemic Agreement is approved in a vote, according to reports from credible sources.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The World Health Assembly (WHA) is the decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO), and it has the authority to approve international agreements related to global health. The Pandemic Agreement, also known as the Pandemic Treaty, is a proposed international agreement aimed at strengthening global pandemic preparedness and response. The agreement has been under negotiation since 2021, and it is expected to be presented for approval at the WHA in May 2024. Given the significance of the Pandemic Agreement and the WHA's role in global health governance, it is likely that the agreement will be approved at the May 2024 WHA. The WHA has a track record of approving important global health agreements, such as the International Health Regulations (2005) and the Global Health Security Agenda (2014). Additionally, the COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for stronger global cooperation and coordination in responding to pandemics, which may increase the likelihood of approval. However, it is also possible that the agreement may face opposition or delays due to various reasons, such as concerns about sovereignty, funding, or implementation. Some member states may also have reservations about certain provisions of the agreement, which could lead to negotiations and potential amendments. Overall, while there are uncertainties surrounding the approval process, the significance of the Pandemic Agreement and the WHA's role in global health governance suggest that approval is more likely than not.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024. To assess the likelihood of this event, we need to consider the legal and political context. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. There have been efforts to invoke this clause to disqualify Trump from running for office due to his alleged role in the January 6, 2021, storming of the U.S. Capitol. However, the process of removing or blocking Trump from the ballot would require a state-level decision, which would likely involve a legal challenge or a formal determination by a state election official. As of the current date (September 12, 2023), there is no clear indication that any state has taken concrete steps to remove Trump from the ballot under Section 3. Given the complexity of the legal process and the uncertainty surrounding the application of Section 3, it is difficult to predict with certainty whether Trump will be removed or blocked from the ballot. However, considering the ongoing investigations and legal challenges related to Trump's alleged involvement in the January 6 events, it is possible that some states might attempt to invoke Section 3 to disqualify him.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.
