question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]
question.body:
Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie.
https://deepnewz.com/movies/deadpool-wolverine-set-record-360m-global-opening-weekend-biggest-r-rated-debut

"""

The film, directed by Shawn Levy and starring Ryan Reynolds, is projected to earn between $340 million and $360 million globally in its opening weekend. This would mark the biggest opening weekend ever for an R-rated movie. Domestically, the film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time.

"""

[image]The record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is the original Deadpool at $284.5M ($152.2M domestic).

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

[image]
Will the new movie top these marks? It will probably be close...

It will certainly play at more theaters... Deadpool was a smash hit at the time, and a bit surprising.

Since BoxOfficeMojo is a bit weird on reporting international opening weekends -- it provides the raw numbers but aggregates them weirdly -- we will wait for Hollywood Reporter to let us know what the weekend opening was.

To clarify on resolution...
-> this market will resolve YES if Deadpool x Wolverine grosses more than $284.5M globally this opening weekend according to reports
-> AND the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

metadata.chain_of_thought: The forecasted opening weekend earnings for the "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie are between $340 million and $360 million globally, with a domestic debut of $160 million to $170 million. This would surpass the current record for the biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie, held by the original Deadpool at $284.5 million. Given the projected earnings and the fact that the movie will play at more theaters, it is likely that the new movie will top the existing record. However, the resolution of this question also depends on the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reporting it as the record for an R-rated movie release.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking whether at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early. According to the provided context from Politico, dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party's effort to seal President Joe Biden's nomination sooner than originally planned. A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.), has been obtained by POLITICO, which suggests that scores of Democrats remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden's candidacy. Huffman has expressed his opposition to the DNC's move, stating that it's a 'really bad move' and that it doesn't work to achieve unity by 'sheer force.' Given the strong language used by Huffman and the fact that dozens of House Democrats are involved in the effort, it seems likely that at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking about the probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. To assess this probability, we need to consider the political climate, the current state of Biden's health, and the likelihood of the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet invoking Section 4. Firstly, the 25th Amendment Section 4 is a rarely used provision that requires a significant consensus among the Vice President and the Cabinet to declare the President incapacitated. Given the current political polarization, it is unlikely that the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet would agree on such a declaration, especially without a clear and compelling reason. Secondly, there is no public information suggesting that President Biden's health is deteriorating to the point where he is unable to discharge his duties. While Biden is 81 years old, he has shown no signs of significant cognitive decline or physical incapacitation that would warrant such a declaration. Lastly, the context provided mentions a GOP lawmaker asking Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office. However, this is likely a political stunt rather than a serious attempt to invoke the 25th Amendment. The Department of Justice, led by Merrick Garland, does not have the authority to invoke the 25th Amendment, and such a move would be seen as a gross overreach of power. Considering these factors, the probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 is extremely low.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question is asking about the probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. To assess this probability, we need to consider several factors, including the current political climate, the health and well-being of President Biden, and the likelihood of the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet invoking Section 4. Firstly, while there have been some concerns about President Biden's age and health, there is no public evidence to suggest that he is currently incapacitated or unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office. Secondly, invoking Section 4 of the 25th Amendment is a serious and drastic measure that would require a significant consensus among the Vice President and the Cabinet. Given the current political polarization and the fact that the Cabinet is appointed by the President, it is unlikely that they would agree to declare him incapacitated without strong evidence. Furthermore, the context provided mentions a GOP lawmaker asking Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office, but this is just a single lawmaker's opinion and not a formal declaration of incapacitation. It is also worth noting that the 25th Amendment is intended to be used in cases of severe incapacitation, such as a coma or a severe mental health crisis, rather than as a political tool to remove a President from office. Considering these factors, the probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 appears to be low.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

Jared Huffman (D-Calif.). The letter offers the first public signal from Democrats that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden's candidacy. Huffman has expressed his opposition to the DNC's plan, stating that it's a 'really bad move' and that it doesn't work to achieve unity. Given the fact that dozens of House Democrats are involved in the effort and a drafted letter has already been circulated, it seems likely that at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question asks whether Donald Trump will gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents when facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat. To answer this, we need to consider the differences in how respondents might vote when given a specific candidate (Joe Biden) versus a generic Democrat. Public opinion polls have consistently shown that Joe Biden performs worse than other Democrats when pitted against Donald Trump. This suggests that respondents may view Biden differently than they do other Democrats, possibly due to his high profile, past performance, or other factors. In contrast, a generic Democrat is a more abstract concept, allowing respondents to project their ideal candidate onto the option. This might lead to a more favorable view of the Democratic candidate, as respondents are not constrained by the specifics of a particular candidate's record or persona. Given these considerations, it's reasonable to assume that Trump might perform better against Biden than against a generic Democrat, as respondents may be more likely to vote for a generic Democrat due to the absence of any specific negative associations. However, the question asks whether Trump will gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents. While it's possible that Trump might perform better against Biden, the difference might not be large enough to meet the 3% threshold.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. To assess the likelihood of this event, we need to consider the legal and political landscape. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, also known as the Disqualification Clause, prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. The clause has been invoked in the past to disqualify individuals from public office, but its application to a former president is unprecedented. There are ongoing efforts to disqualify Trump from the 2024 presidential election under this clause, citing his alleged role in the January 6, 2021, insurrection at the U.S. Capitol. However, the process of disqualification is complex and involves multiple stakeholders, including state governments, courts, and election officials. Given the complexity of the issue and the limited time frame before the resolution date, it is uncertain whether Trump will be officially removed or blocked from any state's primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024.

This must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice.
